{{History of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}} Deliberate destruction and theft of [[cultural heritage]] has been conducted by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]] since 2014 in [[Iraq]], [[Syria]], and to a lesser extent in [[Libya]]. The destruction targets various places of worship under ISIL control and ancient historical artifacts. In Iraq, between the [[fall of Mosul]] in June 2014 and February 2015, ISIL had plundered and destroyed at least 28 historical religious buildings.<ref name="al-shorfa">{{cite web |url=http://mawtani.al-shorfa.com/en_GB/articles/iii/features/2015/02/13/feature-01 |title=Iraq churches, mosques under ISIS attack |author=Khalid al-Taie |publisher=mawtani.al-shorfa.com |date=13 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219092526/http://mawtani.al-shorfa.com/en_GB/articles/iii/features/2015/02/13/feature-01 |archivedate=19 February 2015}}</ref> Valuable items from some buildings were looted in order to smuggle and sell them to foreigners to finance ISIS activities.<ref name="al-shorfa"/> By 23 March 2019, ISIL lost most of its territories in the Middle East, having been defeated in Iraq and Syria.
==Motivation== {{See also|Aniconism in Islam}} ISIL justifies the destruction of cultural heritage sites with its following of [[Salafism]] which, according to its followers, places "great importance on establishing [[tawhid]] (monotheism)", and "eliminating [[Shirk (Islam)|shirk]] (polytheism)." While it is often assumed that the group's actions are mindless acts of vandalism, there is an ideological underpinning to the destruction. ISIL views its actions in sites like Palmyra and Nimrud as being in accordance with Sunni [[Islam]]ic tradition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/religion-geopolitics/commentaries/glance/dont-be-surprised-isis-destroying-history |title=Don't Be Surprised by ISIS Destroying History |publisher=Tony Blair Faith Foundation |access-date=2015-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160803123932/http://tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/religion-geopolitics/commentaries/glance/dont-be-surprised-isis-destroying-history |archive-date=2016-08-03 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
Beyond the ideological aspects of the destruction, there are other, more practical, reasons behind ISIL's destruction of historic sites. Grabbing the world's attention is easily done through the destruction of such sites, given the extensive media coverage and international condemnation that comes afterwards. Destroying historic ruins also allows ISIL to wipe the slate clean and to start afresh, leaving no traces of any previous culture or civilization, while also providing an ideal platform for the group to establish its own identity and leave its mark on history. Despite the images showing extreme destruction, ISIL has also been making use of the looted antiquities to finance their activities.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/15/iraq-isis-arrest-jihadists-wealth-power |title=How an arrest in Iraq revealed Isis's $2bn jihadist network |author=Martin Chulov |work=The Guardian |access-date=2016-12-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616091317/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/15/iraq-isis-arrest-jihadists-wealth-power |archive-date=2014-06-16 |url-status=live }}</ref> Despite the UN's ban on the trade of artifacts looted from Syria since 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/02/12/us-mideast-crisis-un-idUSKBN0LG1YN20150212 |title=U.N. Security Council ups pressure on Islamic State financing |publisher=Reuters UK |access-date=2015-09-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910150453/http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/02/12/us-mideast-crisis-un-idUSKBN0LG1YN20150212 |archive-date=2015-09-10 |url-status=live }}</ref> the group has been smuggling these artifacts out of the Middle East and on to the [[black market|underground antique markets]] of Europe and North America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/religion-geopolitics/commentaries/opinion/why-does-isis-destroy-historic-sites |title=Why Does ISIS Destroy Historic Sites? |work=Tony Blair Faith Foundation |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006100612/http://tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/religion-geopolitics/commentaries/opinion/why-does-isis-destroy-historic-sites |archivedate=2015-10-06 }}</ref>
==Destroyed heritage== {{Main article|Mosques and shrines of Mosul}}[[File:NiniveNabiYunisMinaret.jpg|thumb|[[Mosques and shrines of Mosul#The Mosque of the Prophet Yunus (Jonah)|Prophet Jonah (Nabi Yunus) Mosque]] in Mosul, pictured in 1999. It was destroyed by ISIL in 2014.]]
===Mosques and shrines=== In 2014, media reported destruction of multiple, Sunni and [[Shiite]], mosques and shrines throughout areas captured by ISIL.<ref name="hp">{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/07/isis-destroys-shiite-mosque_n_5564373.html |title=ISIS Destroys Shiite Mosques And Shrines In Iraq, Dangerously Fracturing Country (PHOTOS) |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=7 July 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225113446/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/07/isis-destroys-shiite-mosque_n_5564373.html |archive-date=25 February 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> Among them were the Al-Qubba Husseiniya Mosque in [[Mosul]], [[Sheikh Jawad Al-Sadiq Mosque]], [[Mosque of Arnā’ūt]], [[Mosque of Qado]], [[Mosque of Askar e- Mullah]] and [[Saad Ibn Aqeel Shrine|Saad Bin Aqeel Shrine]] in [[Tal Afar]], [[Sufism|Sufi]] Ahmed al-Rifai Shrine and tomb and Sheikh Ibrahim shrine in Mahlabiya District and the so-called Tomb of the Girl (Qabr al-Bint) in Mosul.<ref name="hp"/> The Tomb of the Girl, reputed to honour a girl who died of a broken heart, was actually believed to be the tomb of medieval scholar [[Ali ibn al-Athir]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/isis-insurgents-wage-war-on-history/article6158435.ece |title=ISIS insurgents wage war on history |work=[[The Hindu]] |author=Praveen Swami |date=29 June 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708210920/http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/isis-insurgents-wage-war-on-history/article6158435.ece |archive-date=8 July 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In June 2014, ISIL bulldozed the two buildings in the complex of the shrine of [[Fathi al-Ka'en]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/06/25/368591/isil-destroys-two-shia-sites-in-mosul |title=ISIL destroys two Shia religious sites in Iraqi city of Mosul |publisher=PressTV |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402103926/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/06/25/368591/isil-destroys-two-shia-sites-in-mosul/ |archive-date=2 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
On 24 September 2014, the [[Arba'een Wali Mosque and Shrine]] in [[Tikrit]], containing forty tombs from the [[Umar]] era, was blown up.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isis-destroys-historical-al-arbain-mosque-tikrit |title=URGENT: ISIS destroys historical Al-Arbain mosque in Tikrit |publisher=Iraqi News |author=Abdelhak Mamoun |date=25 September 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150128041254/http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isis-destroys-historical-al-arbain-mosque-tikrit/ |archive-date=28 January 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 26 February 2015 ISIL blew up the 12th century [[Green Mosque (Mosul)|Green Mosque]] in central Mosul.<ref name="news">{{cite web |url=http://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-updates/ancient-artefacts-destroyed-in-iraq/story-e6frfq80-1227241419029 |title=Ancient artefacts destroyed in Iraq |publisher=News.com.au |date=27 February 2014 |accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref>
In Mosul, ISIL also targeted several tombs with shrines built over them. In July 2014, ISIL destroyed [[Tomb of Daniel#Iraq|one of the tombs of prophet Daniel]] (located in [[Mosul]]) by planted explosives.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/25/isis-jonah-tomb_n_5620520.html |title=ISIS Destroys Jonah's Tomb In Mosul, Iraq, As Militant Violence Continues |last=Hafiz |first=Yasmine |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=25 July 2014 |accessdate=28 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727202017/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/07/25/isis-jonah-tomb_n_5620520.html |archive-date=27 July 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 24 July 2014, the tomb and [[Mosques and shrines of Mosul#The Mosque of the Prophet Yunus (Jonah)|mosque of the prophet Jonah]] was destroyed with explosives.<ref>{{cite news |title=ISIL destroys Mosque of Biblical Jonah, Prophet Yunus |url=http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isil-destroys-mosque-biblical-jonah-prophet-yunus |accessdate=24 July 2014 |work=IraqiNews.com |date=24 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808222034/http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isil-destroys-mosque-biblical-jonah-prophet-yunus |archive-date=8 August 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 27 July, ISIL destroyed the tomb of [[Saint George|Prophet Jirjis (George)]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Islamic State destroys ancient Mosul mosque, the third in a week |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/28/islamic-state-destroys-ancient-mosul-mosque |accessdate=27 July 2014 |publisher=theguardian.com |date=27 July 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728032035/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/28/islamic-state-destroys-ancient-mosul-mosque |archive-date=28 July 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>
On 25 July 2014, the 13th-century shrine of [[Imam Awn al-Din]] in Mosul, one of the few structures to have survived the [[Mongol invasions and conquests#West Asia|13th-century Mongol invasion]], was destroyed by ISIL.{{cn|date=March 2019}} The destruction was mostly carried out with explosive devices, but in some cases bulldozers were used.<ref name="hp"/>
In March 2015, ISIL reportedly bulldozed to the ground the Hamu Al-Qadu Mosque in Mosul, dating back to 1880. The Hamu-Al-Qadu mosque contained an earlier tomb of [[Ala-al-din Ibn Abdul Qadir Gilani]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20150308/1019218229.html |title=ISIL Destroys Another Mosque in Iraq |publisher=[[Sputnik (news agency)|Sputnik]] |date=8 March 2015 |accessdate=10 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402145225/http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20150308/1019218229.html |archive-date=2 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> In the same year ISIL ordered the removal of all decorative elements and frescoes from mosques in Mosul, even those containing [[Quranic]] verses that mention Allah.<ref name="tass">{{cite web |url=http://tass.ru/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/1876232 |title="Исламское государство" заставило имамов Мосула удалять фрески со стен мечетей |publisher=[[Russian News Agency "TASS"]] |language=Russian |date=2 April 2015 |accessdate=22 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408092356/http://tass.ru/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/1876232 |archive-date=8 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> They were regarded by ISIL as "an erroneous form of creativity, contradicting the basics of [[sharia]]." At least one [[imam]] in Mosul opposing that order was shot to death.<ref name="tass"/> [[File:منارة الحدباء.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Leaning minaret of the Great Mosque of Al-nuri. Destroyed by ISIL on 22 June 2017 during the [[Battle of Mosul (2016–present)|Battle of Mosul]].]] ISIL also destroyed [[Sufism|Sufi]] shrines near [[Tripoli]], [[Libya]], in March 2015. The shrines were destroyed by sledgehammers and bulldozers.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Thornhill |first1=Ted |title=ISIS continues its desecration of the Middle East: Islamic State reduces Sufi shrines in Libya to rubble in latest act of mindless destruction |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2987800/ISIS-continues-desecration-Middle-East-Islamic-State-reduces-Sufi-shrines-Libya-rubble-latest-act-mindless-destruction.html |accessdate=12 March 2015 |work=Daily Mail |date=10 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150312061227/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2987800/ISIS-continues-desecration-Middle-East-Islamic-State-reduces-Sufi-shrines-Libya-rubble-latest-act-mindless-destruction.html |archive-date=12 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In June 2015, it was announced that ISIL had blown up the ancient tombs of [[Mohammed bin Ali]] and [[Nizar Abu Bahaaeddine]], located close to the ruins of [[Palmyra]].<ref name="dailymail2015-06-23">{{cite news |last1=Hall |first1=John |title=ISIS begin the destruction of Palmyra: Islamic extremists blow up two mausoleums in the ancient Syrian city... including one belonging to a descendant of the Prophet Mohammed |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3136251/ISIS-begin-destruction-Palmyra-Islamic-extremists-blow-two-mausoleums-ancient-Syrian-city-including-one-belonging-descendant-Prophet-Mohammed.html |accessdate=24 June 2015 |work=[[Daily Mail]] |date=23 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704161547/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3136251/ISIS-begin-destruction-Palmyra-Islamic-extremists-blow-two-mausoleums-ancient-Syrian-city-including-one-belonging-descendant-Prophet-Mohammed.html |archive-date=4 July 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In 2016, ISIL destroyed the [[Minaret of Anah]] located in [[Al Anbar Province]], which dates back to the [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid era]]. The minaret was only rebuilt in 2013 after the destruction by an unknown perpetrator in 2006.<ref>[http://www.almadapaper.net/ar/news/445823/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AD%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A2%D8%AB%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%AA%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%AD-%D9%85%D8%A6%D8%B0%D9%86%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%86%D8%A8 السياحة والآثار تفتتح مئذنة "عنه" في الأنبار بعد ترميمها] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222044731/http://www.almadapaper.net/ar/news/445823/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AD%D8%A9-%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A2%D8%AB%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%AA%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%AD-%D9%85%D8%A6%D8%B0%D9%86%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%86%D9%87-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D9%86%D8%A8 |date=2018-02-22 }}. ''Al-Mada Newspaper''. Retrieved December 29, 2017.</ref><ref>[https://www.algharbiyanews.com/?p=73752 داعش يفجر قلعة عنه الاثرية] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171229231516/https://www.algharbiyanews.com/?p=73752 |date=2017-12-29 }}. ''Al-Garbiya''. Retrieved December 29, 2017.</ref>
In 2017, ISIL destroyed the [[Great Mosque of al-Nuri (Mosul)|Great Mosque of al-Nuri]] and its leaning minaret. This was the mosque where ISIL leader [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]] declared the establishment of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] caliphate three years prior.<ref name="BBC_destruction">{{cite news |title=Battle for Mosul: IS 'blows up' al-Nuri mosque |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40361857 |accessdate=21 June 2017 |work=BBC |date=21 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621215655/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40361857 |archive-date=21 June 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Churches and monasteries=== [[File:Saint Elijah's Monastery 1.JPG|thumb|[[Dair Mar Elia]] monastery, which was destroyed sometime between late August and September 2014]]
In June 2014, it was reported that ISIL elements had been instructed to destroy all churches in Mosul.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/isil-instructs-to-destroy-churches-in-mosul |title=ISIL orders destruction of all churches in Mosul |publisher=Iraqi News |date=16 June 2014 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150331114953/http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/isil-instructs-to-destroy-churches-in-mosul/ |archive-date=31 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> Since then, most churches within the city have been destroyed. * The Virgin Mary Church was destroyed with several [[improvised explosive device]]s in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isil-destroys-virgin-mary-church-mosul |title=URGENT: ISIL destroys the Virgin Mary church in Mosul |publisher=Iraqi News |author=Abdelhak Mamoun |date=26 July 2014 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150228232119/http://www.iraqinews.com/features/urgent-isil-destroys-virgin-mary-church-mosul/ |archive-date=28 February 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> * [[Dair Mar Elia]], the oldest monastery in Iraq, was demolished sometime between late August and September 2014. The destruction went unreported until January 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mendoza |first1=Martha |last2=Alleruzzo |first2=Maya |last3=Janssen |first3=Bram |title=IS Destroys Religious Sites: The oldest Christian monastery in Iraq has been reduced to a field of rubble by IS's relentless destruction of ancient cultural sites |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2016-01-20/only-on-ap-oldest-christian-monastery-in-iraq-is-razed |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=20 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160121031241/http://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2016-01-20/only-on-ap-oldest-christian-monastery-in-iraq-is-razed |archivedate=21 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Iraq's oldest Christian monastery destroyed by Islamic State |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35360415 |work=[[BBC]] |date=20 January 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120155412/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-35360415 |archivedate=20 January 2016}}</ref> * The Al-Tahera Church, built in the early 20th century, was possibly blown up in early February 2015.<ref name="al-shorfa"/> However, there is no evidence that the church was actually destroyed.<ref>{{cite news |title=There is no evidence that the al-Tahera Church (of the Immaculate/Virgin Mary) in Mosul has been destroyed (yet) |url=https://conflictantiquities.wordpress.com/2014/07/29/syria-iraq-mosul-chaldean-church-immaculate-virgin-mary-destruction-propaganda/ |work=conflict antiquities |date=29 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160127192850/https://conflictantiquities.wordpress.com/2014/07/29/syria-iraq-mosul-chaldean-church-immaculate-virgin-mary-destruction-propaganda/ |archivedate=27 January 2016}}</ref> * St Markourkas Church, a 10th-century [[Chaldean Catholic]] church, was destroyed on 9 March 2015, according to the Iraqi government official Dureid Hikmat Tobia. A nearby cemetery was also bulldozed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldbulletin.net/news/156360/isil-destroys-historical-church-in-mosul |title=ISIL destroys historical church in Mosul |publisher=Worldbulletin News |date=10 March 2015 |accessdate=10 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402133410/http://www.worldbulletin.net/news/156360/isil-destroys-historical-church-in-mosul |archive-date=2 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> * Another church, which was reportedly "thousands of years" old, was blown up in July 2015. According to Kurdish sources, four children were inadvertently killed when the church was destroyed.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gander |first1=Kashmira |title=Isis 'kills four children' as it reportedly destroys ancient church in Iraqi city of Mosul |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-kills-four-children-as-it-destroys-ancient-church-in-iraqi-city-of-mosul-10376301.html |accessdate=12 July 2015 |work=[[The Independent]] |date=8 July 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711032940/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-kills-four-children-as-it-destroys-ancient-church-in-iraqi-city-of-mosul-10376301.html |archive-date=11 July 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> * The Sa'a Qadima Church, which was built in 1872, was blown up in April 2016.<ref>{{cite news |title=ISIS extremists bomb historic church in Mosul |url=http://aranews.net/2016/04/isis-extremists-bomb-historic-church-mosul/ |work=ARA News |date=28 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160501101758/http://aranews.net/2016/04/isis-extremists-bomb-historic-church-mosul/ |archivedate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Latin Church, Mosul, 1940s-3.jpg|thumb|left|The Sa'a Qadima Church in Mosul, blown up in April 2016]]
ISIL also blew up or demolished a number of other churches elsewhere in Iraq or in Syria. The [[Armenian Genocide Memorial Church, Der Zor|Armenian Genocide Memorial Church]] in [[Deir ez-Zor]], Syria was blown up by ISIL militants on 21 September 2014.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hayrumyan |first1=Naira |title=Middle East Terror: Memory of Armenian Genocide victims targeted by ISIS militants |url=http://www.armenianow.com/commentary/analysis/57070/armenia_church_syria_isis_aram_catholicos |work=[[ArmeniaNow]] |date=24 September 2014 |access-date=7 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905144120/http://www.armenianow.com/commentary/analysis/57070/armenia_church_syria_isis_aram_catholicos |archive-date=5 September 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=IS said to destroy Armenian Genocide memorial |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/is-reportedly-destroys-armenian-genocide-memorial |work=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=22 September 2014 |access-date=7 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150628203715/http://www.timesofisrael.com/is-reportedly-destroys-armenian-genocide-memorial/ |archive-date=28 June 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
On 24 September 2014 ISIL militants destroyed with improvised explosive devices the [[Saint Ahoadamah Church, Tikrit|7th-century Green Church]] (also known as St Ahoadamah Church) belonging to the [[Assyrian Church of the East]] in [[Tikrit]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.english.alahednews.com.lb/essaydetails.php?eid=27364&cid=547#.VPC5O46rEYI |title=ISIL Destroys VII-century Church, Historical Mosque in Iraq |publisher=Alahednews |date=26 September 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095458/http://www.english.alahednews.com.lb/essaydetails.php?eid=27364&cid=547#.VPC5O46rEYI |archive-date=2 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
The [[Mar Behnam Monastery]] in [[Khidr Ilyas]] near [[Bakhdida]], Iraq was destroyed by ISIL in March 2015.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mezzofiore |first1=Gianluca |title=Isis 'blows up famed 4th-century Mar Behnam Catholic monastery' in Iraq |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/isis-blows-famed-4th-century-mar-behnam-catholic-monastery-iraq-1492703 |accessdate=30 March 2016 |work=[[International Business Times]] |date=19 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416143819/http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/isis-blows-famed-4th-century-mar-behnam-catholic-monastery-iraq-1492703 |archive-date=16 April 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Christopher |title=Another Treasure Lost in Iraq: The Story of Mar Behnam Monastery |url=http://hyperallergic.com/216393/another-treasure-lost-in-iraq-the-story-of-mar-behnam-monastery/ |accessdate=24 October 2016 |work=[[Hyperallergic]] |date=23 June 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027095857/http://hyperallergic.com/216393/another-treasure-lost-in-iraq-the-story-of-mar-behnam-monastery/ |archive-date=27 October 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref>
{{As of|2015|4|5}}, ISIL destroyed the Assyrian Christian Virgin Mary Church on Easter Sunday in the Syrian town of Tel Nasri. "As the 'joint forces' of Kurdish [[People's Protection Units]] and local Assyrian fighters attempted to enter the town", ISIL set off the explosives destroying what remained of the church.<ref name="ISIS blew up a Syrian church on Easter">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/isis-blew-up-an-assyrian-church-on-easter-2015-4?nr_email_referer=1 |title=ISIS blew up a Syrian church on Easter |publisher=Now Lebanon via Business Insider |date=6 April 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011221849/http://www.businessinsider.com/isis-blew-up-an-assyrian-church-on-easter-2015-4?nr_email_referer=1 |archive-date=11 October 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> ISIL had controlled the church since 7 March 2015.<ref name="ISIS blew up a Syrian church on Easter"/>
On 21 August 2015, the historic [[Monastery of St. Elian]] near [[Al-Qaryatayn]] in the [[Homs Governorate]] was destroyed by ISIL.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_ISLAMIC_STATE?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |title=News from The Associated Press |accessdate=21 August 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141109114112/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_ISLAMIC_STATE?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |archivedate=9 November 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/599816/ISIS-Islamic-State-Mar-Elian-monastery-Homs-Syria-bulldoze-saint |title=Islamic State: ISIS digs up saint's bones after bulldozing Christian church in Syria |author=Nick Gutteridge |work=Express.co.uk |accessdate=21 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150822005422/http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/599816/ISIS-Islamic-State-Mar-Elian-monastery-Homs-Syria-bulldoze-saint |archive-date=22 August 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Ancient and medieval sites=== {{see also|Destruction of Mosul Museum artifacts}} [[File:Tal Afar Castle.jpg|thumb|The [[Tal Afar Citadel]], which was partially destroyed in December 2014]]
In May 2014, ISIL members smashed a 3,000-year-old neo-Assyrian statue from Tel Ajaja.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=3bded8ec5c36418ba53318e76808babb |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-08-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160919201504/https://www.arcgis.com/home/item.html?id=3bded8ec5c36418ba53318e76808babb |archive-date=2016-09-19 |url-status=live }}</ref> Later reports indicated that over 40% of the artifacts at Tel Ajaja (Saddikanni) were looted by ISIS.<ref>AFP, At ancient Syria site, IS discovers then destroys treasures, Aug. 7 2016, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UCzc0uJElGs</ref>
Parts of the [[Tal Afar Citadel]] were blown up by ISIL in December 2014, causing extensive damage.<ref>{{cite news |title=Extremist IS militants damage ancient citadel, two shrines in Iraq's Nineveh |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-12/31/c_133890461.htm |work=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=31 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113075719/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2014-12/31/c_133890461.htm |archivedate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Jones |first1=Christopher |title=ISIS destroys several more sites in Mosul and Tal Afar |url=https://gatesofnineveh.wordpress.com/2015/02/10/isis-destroys-several-more-sites-in-mosul-and-tal-afar/ |website=Gates of Nineveh |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020756/https://gatesofnineveh.wordpress.com/2015/02/10/isis-destroys-several-more-sites-in-mosul-and-tal-afar/ |archivedate=5 March 2016 |date=15 February 2015}}</ref>
In January 2015, ISIL reportedly destroyed large parts of the [[Nineveh#City wall and gates|Nineveh Wall]] in al-Tahrir neighborhood of Mosul.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/isis-detonates-large-parts-nineveh-historical-wall |title=ISIS detonates large parts of Nineveh historical wall |publisher=Iraqi News |author=Abdelhak Mamoun |date=28 January 2015 |accessdate=28 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309092235/http://www.iraqinews.com/iraq-war/isis-detonates-large-parts-nineveh-historical-wall/ |archive-date=9 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> Further parts of the walls, including the Mashka and Adad Gate, were blown up in April 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Celeng |first1=Sozbin |last2=Yousef |first2=Sarbaz |title=ISIS extremists destroy parts of Nineveh ancient wall northern Iraq |url=http://aranews.net/2016/04/isis-extremists-destroy-parts-nineveh-ancient-wall-northern-iraq/ |work=ARA News |date=16 April 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421151134/http://aranews.net/2016/04/isis-extremists-destroy-parts-nineveh-ancient-wall-northern-iraq/ |archivedate=21 April 2016}}</ref>
In the Syrian city of [[Raqqa]], ISIL publicly ordered the bulldozing of a colossal [[Assyrian sculpture|ancient Assyrian gateway lion sculpture]] from the 8th century BC.<ref name="usdep">{{cite web |url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/09/232028.htm |title=Threats to Cultural Heritage in Iraq and Syria |publisher=US Department of State |date=23 September 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170121130323/https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/09/232028.htm |archive-date=21 January 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> Another lion statue was also destroyed. Both statues originated from the [[Arslan Tash]] archaeological site.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/safeguarding-syrian-cultural-heritage/arslan-tash |title=Lion statues destroyed |publisher=UNESCO |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403080446/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/safeguarding-syrian-cultural-heritage/arslan-tash/ |archive-date=3 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> The destruction was published in the ISIL magazine, ''[[Dabiq (magazine)|Dabiq]]''. Among the lost statues are those of Mulla Uthman al-Mawsili, of a woman carrying an urn, and of [[Abu Tammam]].{{cn|date=March 2019}}
On 26 February 2015, ISIL released a video showing the destruction of various ancient artifacts in the [[Mosul Museum]].<ref name="news"/> The affected artifacts originate from the [[Assyria]]n era and from the ancient city of [[Hatra]].<ref name="news"/> The video in particular shows the defacement of a granite [[lamassu]] statue from the right side of the [[Nergal Gate]] by a jackhammer. The statue remained buried until 1941 when heavy rains eroded the soil around the gate and exposed two statues on both sides.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsmax.com/US/ISIS-radical-islam-Mosul/2015/03/02/id/627831 |title=What's Been Lost to Radical Islamists' Sledgehammers |publisher=[[Newsmax Media]] |author=John Burger |date=2 March 2015 |accessdate=8 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308121840/http://www.newsmax.com/US/ISIS-radical-islam-Mosul/2015/03/02/id/627831/ |archive-date=8 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> Several other defaced items in the museum were claimed to be copies,<ref name="news"/> but this was later rebutted by Iraq's Minister of Culture, Adel Sharshab who said: "Mosul Museum had many ancient artifacts, big and small. None of them were transported to the [[National Museum of Iraq]] in Baghdad. Thus, all artifacts destroyed in Mosul are original except for four pieces that were made of [[gypsum]]".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20150312/1019414970.html |title=ISIL Destroyed Original Artifacts, Not Copies – Iraqi Culture Minister |publisher=[[Sputnik (news agency)|Sputnik]] |date=12 March 2015 |accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Iraq; Nimrud - Assyria, Lamassu's Guarding Palace Entrance.jpg|thumb|left|Palace of [[Ashurnasirpal II]] in [[Nimrud]], pictured in 2007. ISIL reportedly bulldozed the city in March 2015]]
On 5 March 2015, ISIL reportedly started the demolition of [[Nimrud]], an Assyrian city from the 13th century BC. The local palace was bulldozed, while lamassu statues at the gates of the palace of [[Ashurnasirpal II]] were smashed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/isil-fighters-bulldoze-ancient-assyrian-palace-iraq-150305195222805.html |title=ISIL fighters bulldoze ancient Assyrian palace in Iraq |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=5 March 2015 |accessdate=6 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180224031022/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/03/isil-fighters-bulldoze-ancient-assyrian-palace-iraq-150305195222805.html |archive-date=24 February 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> A video showing the destruction of Nimrud was released in April 2015.<ref>{{cite news |title='IS destruction of Nimrud' on video |url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150412/world/is-destruction-of-nimrud-on-video.563644 |accessdate=12 April 2015 |work=TimesofMalta.com |date=12 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415025443/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150412/world/is-destruction-of-nimrud-on-video.563644 |archive-date=15 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
On 7 March 2015, Kurdish sources reported that ISIL had begun the bulldozing of [[Hatra]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.riyadhvision.com/2015/03/07/reports-isis-bulldozed-ancient-hatra-city-in-mosul |title=Reports: ISIS bulldozed ancient Hatra city in Mosul |work=RiyadhVision |date=7 March 2015 |accessdate=8 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315094537/http://www.riyadhvision.com/2015/03/07/reports-isis-bulldozed-ancient-hatra-city-in-mosul/ |archive-date=15 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Yacoub |first=Sameer N. |agency=Associated Press |date=7 March 2015 |title=IS destroying another ancient archaeological site in Iraq |url=http://www.armytimes.com/story/military/2015/03/07/is-destroying-another-ancient-archaeological-site-in-iraq/24556625 |newspaper=ArmyTimes |location=USA|access-date=7 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="bbc-hatra">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31779484 |title=Islamic state 'demolish' ancient Hatra site in Iraq |accessdate=15 August 2015 |publisher=BBC |date=7 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817192846/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31779484 |archive-date=17 August 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> which has been under threat of demolition after ISIL had occupied the adjacent area. The next day ISIL sacked [[Dur-Sharrukin]], according to a Kurdish official from Mosul, Saeed Mamuzini.<ref name="star">{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/03/08/ancient-site-khorsabad-attacked-by-islamic-state-reports.html |title=Ancient site Khorsabad attacked by Islamic State: reports |work=[[Toronto Star]] |date=8 March 2015 |accessdate=8 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309174534/http://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/03/08/ancient-site-khorsabad-attacked-by-islamic-state-reports.html |archive-date=9 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
The Iraqi Tourism and Antiquities Ministry launched the related investigation on the same day.<ref name="star"/> On 8 April 2015, the Iraqi Ministry of Tourism reported that ISIL destroyed the remnants of the 12th-century [[Bash Tapia Castle]] in Mosul.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tass.ru/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/1889000 |title=Боевики "Исламского государства" взорвали древний замок Баш Тапия в иракском Мосуле |publisher=[[Russian News Agency "TASS"]] |language=Russian |date=8 April 2015 |accessdate=22 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908171408/http://tass.ru/mezhdunarodnaya-panorama/1889000 |archive-date=8 September 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> As of early July 2015, 20% of Iraq's 10,000 archaeological sites has been under ISIL control.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33369701 |title=Islamic State militants 'destroy Palmyra statues' |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2 July 2015 |accessdate=3 July 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702185932/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33369701 |archive-date=2 July 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In 2015 the face of the Winged Bull of Nineveh was damaged.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-35669056 |title=Museum of Lost Objects: The Winged Bull of Nineveh |website=BBC News |language=en-GB |access-date=2016-03-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229223729/http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-35669056 |archive-date=2016-02-29 |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Palmyra==== [[File:Temple of Bel, Palmyra 02.jpg|thumb|[[Temple of Bel]] in [[Palmyra]], which was blown up by ISIL in August 2015]] Following the [[Tadmur offensive (2015)|capture of Palmyra]] in Syria, ISIL was reported as not intending to demolish the city's World Heritage Site (while still intending to destroy any statues deemed '[[Polytheism|polytheistic]]').<ref name="theguardian">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/27/isis-releases-footage-of-palmyra-ruins-intact |title=Syria: Isis releases footage of Palmyra ruins intact and 'will not destroy them' |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=29 May 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150527210450/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/may/27/isis-releases-footage-of-palmyra-ruins-intact |archive-date=27 May 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> On 27 May 2015, ISIL released an 87-second video showing parts of the apparently undamaged ancient [[colonnade]]s, the [[Temple of Bel]] and the [[Roman Theatre at Palmyra|Roman theatre]].<ref name="theguardian"/> On 27 June 2015, however, ISIL demolished the ancient [[Lion of Al-lāt]] statue in Palmyra. (It has since been restored, and is in storage in a Damascus museum until it can be determined that the statue can be safely returned to Palmyra.) Several other statues from Palmyra reportedly confiscated from a smuggler were also destroyed by ISIL.<ref name="bbc"/> On 23 August 2015, it was reported that ISIL had blown up the 1st-century [[Temple of Baalshamin]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-34036644 Palmyra's Baalshamin temple 'blown up by IS'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181004002300/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-34036644 |date=2018-10-04 }}, BBC</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/23/isis-blows-up-temple-dating-back-to-17ad-in-unesco-listed-syrian-city Isis 'blows up temple dating back to 17AD' in Syrian city of Palmyra] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180613085035/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/23/isis-blows-up-temple-dating-back-to-17ad-in-unesco-listed-syrian-city |date=2018-06-13 }}, TheGuardian.com; accessed 25 August 2015.</ref> On 30 August 2015, ISIL demolished the [[Temple of Bel]] with explosives. Satellite imagery of the site taken shortly after showed almost nothing remained.<ref>{{cite web |title=Palmyra's Temple of Bel 'destroyed' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34111092 |website=BBC News |publisher=BBC |accessdate=31 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903005143/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-34111092 |archive-date=3 September 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
According to the report issued on September 3, 2015 by ASOR Syrian Heritage initiative, ISIL also destroyed seven ancient tower tombs in Palmyra since the end of June over two phases.<ref name="natpost">{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/intolerable-crime-against-civilization-isil-destroys-three-ancient-tower-tombs-in-palmyra |title=In latest round of destruction, ISIL reduces three ancient tower tombs in Palmyra to rubble |work=[[National Post]] |date=September 4, 2015 |accessdate=September 4, 2015 |archive-url=http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20160507072720/http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/intolerable-crime-against-civilization-isil-destroys-three-ancient-tower-tombs-in-palmyra |archive-date=May 7, 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> The last phase of destruction occurred between August 27 and September 2, 2015, including the destruction of the 2nd-century AD [[Tower of Elahbel]], called "the most prominent example of Palmyra's distinct funerary monuments".<ref name="natpost"/> Earlier, the ancient tombs of Iamliku and Atenaten were also destroyed.<ref name="natpost"/> The [[Monumental Arch of Palmyra|Monumental Arch]] was also blown up in October.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shaheen |first1=Kareem |title=Isis blows up Arch of Triumph in 2,000-year-old city of Palmyra |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/05/isis-blows-up-another-monument-in-2000-year-old-city-of-palmyra |accessdate=5 October 2015 |work=The Guardian |date=5 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005231919/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/05/isis-blows-up-another-monument-in-2000-year-old-city-of-palmyra |archive-date=5 October 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
When Palmyra was [[Palmyra offensive (March 2016)|recaptured]] by Syrian government forces in March 2016, retreating ISIL fighters blew up parts of the 13th-century [[Palmyra Castle]], causing extensive damage.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Said |first1=H. |last2=Raslan |first2=Rasha |last3=Sabbagh |first3=Hazem |title=Palmyra Castle partially damaged due to ISIS acts, plans to restore it to its former glory |url=http://sana.sy/en/?p=72903 |work=[[Syrian Arab News Agency]] |date=26 March 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327133431/http://sana.sy/en/?p=72903 |archivedate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
ISIL has also looted and demolished the [[Parthian Empire|Parthian]]/[[Ancient Rome|Roman]] city of [[Dura-Europos]] in east of Syria.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/09/232028.htm |title=We're sorry, that page can't be found. |website=www.state.gov |accessdate=23 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170121130323/https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2014/09/232028.htm |archive-date=21 January 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> Nicknamed "the [[Pompeii]] of the desert", the city was of particular archaeological significance.
It was reported on 1 January 2019 that Syrian authorities recovered two Roman-era funerary busts smuggled from Palmyra from an abandoned ISIL site in the [[Al-Sukhnah, Syria|Al-Sukhnah]] countryside.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-authorities-recover-2-roman-era-artifacts-from-isis/ |title=Syrian authorities recover 2 Roman-era artifacts from ISIS |access-date=2019-01-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190104074258/https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/syrian-authorities-recover-2-roman-era-artifacts-from-isis/ |archive-date=2019-01-04 |url-status=live }}</ref>
====Hatra==== [[Hatra]] ({{lang-ar|الحضر|al-Ḥaḍr}}) was an ancient city in the Ninawa Governorate and al-Jazira region of Iraq. A large fortified city and capital of the first Arab Kingdom, Hatra withstood invasions by the Romans in A.D. 116 and 198 thanks to its high, thick walls reinforced by towers.<ref name="whc.unesco.org">{{Cite web |url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/277 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2019-12-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191231003404/https://whc.unesco.org/en/list/277 |archive-date=2019-12-31 |url-status=live }}</ref> However about 240 ce, the city fell to Shāpūr I (reigned c. 240–272), the ruler of the Persian Sāsānian dynasty, and was destroyed.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Hatra |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-07-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820000142/https://www.britannica.com/place/Hatra |archive-date=2018-08-20 |url-status=live }}</ref> The remains of the city, especially the temples where Hellenistic and Roman architecture blend with Eastern decorative features, attest to the greatness of its civilization.<ref name="whc.unesco.org"/> The city lies 290 km (180 mi) northwest of Baghdad and 110 km (68 mi) southwest of Mosul. On 7 March 2015, various sources including Iraqi officials reported that the militant group Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) had begun demolishing the ruins of Hatra.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-03-08/islamic-state-militants-raze-iraq-ancient-hatra-city/6288618 |title=IS continues cultural cleansing of Iraq with Hatra's destruction: UNESCO |date=8 March 2015 |publisher= |accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref> Video released by ISIL the next month showed destruction of the monuments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/bcdd18ddfe5143f08e5e2335e19e5af9/video-islamic-state-group-shot-hammered-away-iraqs-hatra |title=Video: Islamic State group shot, hammered away Iraq's Hatra |publisher= |accessdate=23 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407002201/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/bcdd18ddfe5143f08e5e2335e19e5af9/video-islamic-state-group-shot-hammered-away-iraqs-hatra |archive-date=7 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> The ancient city was recaptured by the [[Popular Mobilization Forces]] on 26 April 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-39726244 |title=IS conflict: Iraqi force 'retakes ancient city of Hatra' |date=26 April 2017 |publisher= |accessdate=23 June 2017 |via=www.bbc.co.uk |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604220753/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-39726244 |archive-date=4 June 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref>
===Libraries===
ISIL has burned or stolen collections of books and papers from various locations, including the [[Central Library of Mosul]] (which they rigged with explosives and burned down),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/isis-burns-down-mosul-library-destroys-8000-rare-books-manuscripts-624375 |title=Isis Burns Down Mosul Library, Destroys 8,000 Rare Books and Manuscripts |first=Johnlee |last=Varghese |publisher= |accessdate=23 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160320181623/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/isis-burns-down-mosul-library-destroys-8000-rare-books-manuscripts-624375 |archive-date=20 March 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> the library at the [[University of Mosul]], a Sunni Muslim library, a 265-year-old Latin Church and Monastery of the Dominican Fathers, and the Mosul Museum Library. Some destroyed or stolen works date back to 5000 BC and include "Iraq newspapers dating to the early 20th century, maps and books from the Ottoman Empire, and book collections contributed by about 100 of Mosul’s establishment families." The stated goal is to destroy all non-Islamic books.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/islamic-state-hijacks-mosul-university-chemistry-lab-for-making-bombs-1459503003 |title=Islamic State Hijacks Mosul University Chemistry Lab for Making Bombs |last=London |first=Margaret Coker in |date=2016-04-01 |last2=Baghdad |first2=Ben Kesling in |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |issn=0099-9660 |access-date=2017-01-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170127222913/http://www.wsj.com/articles/islamic-state-hijacks-mosul-university-chemistry-lab-for-making-bombs-1459503003 |archive-date=2017-01-27 |url-status=live }}</ref>
==Response== On 22 September 2014, the United States Secretary of State [[John Kerry]] announced that the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] had partnered with the American Schools of Orient Research Cultural Heritage Initiatives to "comprehensively document the condition of, and threats to, cultural heritage sites in Iraq and Syria to assess their future restoration, preservation, and protection needs".<ref name="usdep"/> In 2014, the [[UNESCO]]'s Committee for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict condemned at the Ninth Meeting "repeated and deliberate attacks against cultural property... in particular in the Syrian Arab Republic and the Republic of Iraq".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/syria-crisis-response/regional-response/single-view/news/reinforce_the_immunity_of_our_common_heritage_under_threat/#.VPDhTY6rEYJ |title=Reinforce the immunity of our common heritage under threat |publisher=UNESCO |date=21 December 2014 |accessdate=27 February 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404194831/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/syria-crisis-response/regional-response/single-view/news/reinforce_the_immunity_of_our_common_heritage_under_threat/#.VPDhTY6rEYJ |archive-date=4 April 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> UNESCO Director-General [[Irina Bokova]] called the destructions in Mosul a violation of the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2199]],<ref name="news"/> and the destruction of Nimrud a [[war crime]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nimrud: Outcry as IS bulldozers attack ancient Iraq site |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31760656 |accessdate=6 March 2015 |work=BBC News |date=6 March 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150306080519/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-31760656 |archive-date=6 March 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Former Prime Minister of Iraq [[Nouri al-Maliki]] reported that the local parliamentary tourism and antiquities committee had "filed complaints with the UN to condemn all ISIL crimes and abuses, including those that affect ancient places of worship".<ref name="al-shorfa"/> On 28 May 2015, the [[United Nations General Assembly]] unanimously passed a resolution, initiated by Germany and Iraq and sponsored by 91 UN member states, stating that ISIL's destruction of cultural heritage may amount to a war crime and urging international measures to halt such acts, which it described as a "tactic of war".<ref>[https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/RES/69/281|UNGA Resolution 69/281], un.org; accessed 15 August 2015.</ref>
After the Palmyra temple's destruction in August 2015, the [[Institute for Digital Archaeology]] (IDA) announced plans to establish a digital record of historical sites and artifacts threatened by ISIL advance.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sparpointgroup.com/news/vol13no35-oxford-3d |title=Oxford Deploying 5,000 Modified 3D Cameras to Fight ISIS |author=Sean Higgins |work=sparpointgroup.com |access-date=2015-09-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923193440/http://www.sparpointgroup.com/news/vol13no35-oxford-3d |archive-date=2015-09-23 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20150902/1026494356/Middle-East-ruins-digital-preservation.html#ixzz3kgt8e2xo |title=Protecting History: The Digital Project Preserving Artifacts From ISIL Ruin |author=Sputnik |date=2 September 2015 |work=sputniknews.com |access-date=24 September 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924155945/http://sputniknews.com/middleeast/20150902/1026494356/Middle-East-ruins-digital-preservation.html#ixzz3kgt8e2xo |archive-date=24 September 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=BBCToday>{{cite news |title=The digital race against IS |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p030ys68 |accessdate=24 September 2015 |work=BBC Radio 4 "Today" programme |agency=BBC |date=28 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150831012112/http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p030ys68 |archive-date=31 August 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=ArchDaily>{{cite news |last1=Rosenfield |first1=Karissa |title=Harvard and Oxford Take On ISIS with Digital Preservation Campaign |url=http://www.archdaily.com/772902/harvard-and-oxford-take-on-isis-with-digital-preservation-campaign |accessdate=24 September 2015 |work=Arch Daily |date=1 September 2015}}</ref> To accomplish this goal, the IDA, in collaboration with [[UNESCO World Heritage Site|UNESCO]], will deploy 5,000 3D cameras to partners in the Middle East.<ref name=CNN>{{cite news |last1=Mackay |first1=Mairi |title=Indiana Jones with a 3-D camera? Hi-tech fight to save antiquities from ISIS |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/28/middleeast/3d-mapping-ancient-monuments/ |accessdate=24 September 2015 |work=CNN |date=31 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926100727/http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/28/middleeast/3d-mapping-ancient-monuments/ |archive-date=26 September 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref> The cameras will be used to capture 3D scans of local ruins and relics.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://observer.com/2015/09/can-3-d-imaging-save-ancient-art-from-isis/ |title=Can 3-D Imaging Save Ancient Art from ISIS? |author=Alanna Martinez |work=Observer |access-date=2015-09-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925091341/http://observer.com/2015/09/can-3-d-imaging-save-ancient-art-from-isis/ |archive-date=2015-09-25 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://on.rt.com/6q3c |title=Scientists to flood Middle East with 1,000s of 3D cameras to 'save' ancient sites from ISIS |work=RT English}}</ref><ref name=Forbes>{{cite news |last1=Martin |first1=Guy |title=How England's Institute Of Digital Archeology Will Preserve The Art Isis Wants to Destroy |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/guymartin/2015/08/31/how-englands-institute-of-digital-archeology-will-preserve-the-art-isis-wants-to-destroy/ |accessdate=24 September 2015 |work=Forbes |date=31 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925091421/http://www.forbes.com/sites/guymartin/2015/08/31/how-englands-institute-of-digital-archeology-will-preserve-the-art-isis-wants-to-destroy/ |archive-date=25 September 2015 |url-status=live }}</ref>
The general director of the [[National Museum (Prague)|Czech National Museum]], Michal Lukeš, signed an agreement in June 2017 committing the institution to help Syria save, preserve and conserve much of its cultural and historical heritage damaged by war, including the ancient site of Palmyra; he met with Maamoun Abdulkarim and discussed plans for the works that are said to last until 2019.<ref name=czradio>{{cite news |last1=Johnstone |first1=Chris |title=Czechs sign up to help save Syrian cultural heritage |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/panorama/czechs-sign-up-to-help-save-syrian-cultural-heritage |accessdate=24 June 2017 |work=Radio Praha |date=17 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170523052039/http://www.radio.cz/en/section/panorama/czechs-sign-up-to-help-save-syrian-cultural-heritage |archive-date=23 May 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In June 2017, The World Monuments Fund (WMF) announced launching a £500,000 scheme to train Syrian refugees near the Syrian-Jordanian border in traditional stone masonry. The aim is teaching them to develop skills necessary to be able to help in restoring cultural heritage sites that have been damaged or destroyed during the Syrian Civil War once peace is restored to Syria.<ref name=theart>{{cite news |last1=Shaw |first1=Anny |title=Syrian refugees to be trained to rebuild Palmyra and other heritage sites |url=http://theartnewspaper.com/news/news/syrian-refugees-to-be-trained-in-traditional-stone-masonry-to-rebuild-palmyra-and-other-heritage-sit/ |accessdate=24 June 2017 |work=The Art Newspaper |date=21 June 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170624090053/http://theartnewspaper.com/news/news/syrian-refugees-to-be-trained-in-traditional-stone-masonry-to-rebuild-palmyra-and-other-heritage-sit/ |archive-date=2017-06-24 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
Minor restorations have already begun: Palmyrene funerary busts of a deceased man and a woman, damaged and defaced by ISIL, were taken from Palmyra, then to [[Beirut]] to be sent off to Rome.<ref name=squires>{{cite news |last1=Squires |first1=Nick |title=Stone sculptures smashed by Isil in ancient city of Palmyra restored to former glory by Italian experts |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/16/stone-sculptures-smashed-isil-ancient-city-palmyra-restored/ |accessdate=24 June 2017 |work=Telegraph.co.uk |date=16 February 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812113100/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/16/stone-sculptures-smashed-isil-ancient-city-palmyra-restored/ |archive-date=12 August 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=didonato>{{cite news |last1=Di Donato |first1=Valentine |last2=Said-Moorhouse |first2=Lauren |title=Palmyra treasures restored after ISIS hammer attack |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/17/europe/palmyra-treasures-restored-isis/index.html |accessdate=24 June 2017 |work=[[CNN]] |date=17 February 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170407114709/http://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/17/europe/palmyra-treasures-restored-isis/index.html |archive-date=7 April 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> Italian experts restored the portraits using 3D technology to print resin prosthetics, which were coated with a thick layer of stone dust to blend in with the original stone; the prosthetics were attached to the damaged faces of the busts using strong magnets.<ref name="didonato"/><ref name="squires"/> The restored pieces are now back in Syria.<ref name="squires"/> Abdulkarim said the restoration of the busts "is the first real, visible positive step that the international community has taken to protect Syrian heritage".<ref name="squires"/>
However, the [[Rewards for Justice Program]] offers up to $5 million for information leading to disrupt the sale and/or trade of oil and antiquities by ISIL.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://rewardsforjustice.net/english/trafficking_oil_and_antiquities.html |publisher=Rewards for Justice |title=Trafficking in Oil and Antiquities Benefitting the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) |accessdate=1 August 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190801200713/https://rewardsforjustice.net/english/trafficking_oil_and_antiquities.html |archive-date=1 August 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref>

A Saudi Arabian-led [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|military intervention in Yemen]] began in 2015, in an attempt to influence the outcome of the [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|Yemeni Civil War]]. Saudi Arabia, spearheading a coalition of nine Arab states, began carrying out airstrikes<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sott.net/article/366803-UN-humanitarian-coordinator-shocked-by-Saudi-atrocities-in-Yemen|title=UN humanitarian coordinator "shocked" by Saudi atrocities in Yemen -- Sott.net|website=Sott.net}}</ref> in neighbouring Yemen and imposing an aerial and naval [[blockade of Yemen|blockade]] on 26 March 2015, heralding a military intervention code-named Operation Decisive Storm<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/03/26/GCC-states-to-repel-Houthi-aggression-in-Yemen-statement-.html|title=Saudi ‘Decisive Storm’ waged to save Yemen|website=english.alarabiya.net}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|عملية عاصفة الحزم|translit=Amaliyyat `Āṣifat al-Ḥazm}}). More than 70 health facilities in Yemen have been destroyed by a series of [[airstrike]]s conducted by the Saudi Arabian-led [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|coalition]] since March 2015. Many of these have been public health hospitals staffed or supported by [[Médecins Sans Frontières|Doctors Without Borders]] (MSF).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/yemen|title=Yemen - Doctors Without Borders - USA|website=www.doctorswithoutborders.org}}</ref> Critics of the assaults say the airstrikes are [[war crime]]s in violation of the protections of health care facilities afforded by the [[Geneva Convention|internationally recognized rules of war]] and have called for independent investigations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-39651265|title=Saudi blacklist call over Yemen attacks|date=20 April 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
Many other civilians targets, including schools,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2015/12/bombing-of-schools-by-saudi-arabia-led-coalition-in-yemen/|title=Bombing of schools by Saudi Arabia-led coalition a flagrant attack on future of Yemen’s children|website=www.amnesty.org}}</ref> and school buses<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/aug/09/dozens-dead-in-yemen-as-bus-carrying-children-hit-by-airstrike-icrc|title=Dozens dead in Yemen as bus carrying children hit by airstrike|first=Saeed Kamali|last=Dehghan|date=9 August 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref> in Yemen are also bombed by the Saudi-led coalition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/14/world/middleeast/yemen-saudi-bombing-houthis-hunger.html|title=U.S. Fingerprints on Attacks Obliterating Yemen’s Economy|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/saudi-arabia-coalition-air-strikes-hit-yemen-school-civilian-deaths-sana-drones-donald-trump-a7540316.html|title=Saudi-led coalition air strikes 'hit Yemen school'|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/jul/20/un-warned-not-to-whitewash-grave-violations-against-children-yemen-united-nations|title=UN warned not to whitewash 'grave violations against children' in Yemen|first=Rebecca|last=Ratcliffe|date=19 July 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/un-saudi-arabia-yemen-air-strikes-violated-international-law-a7372936.html|title=The UN just accused Saudi Arabia led coalition of war crimes|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/death-toll-from-saudi-airstrike-on-yemeni-wedding-rises-to-88-report/|title=Death toll from Saudi airstrike on Yemeni wedding rises to 88: report|date=23 April 2018|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/02/world/middleeast/saudi-yemen-bombings.html|title=Saudi Bombing Is Said to Kill Yemeni Civilians Seeking Relief From the Heat|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.presstv.com/Detail/2018/07/27/569428/yemen-hudaydah-airstrikes|title=PressTV-Yemen's Hudaydah goes through another day of airstrikes|publisher=}}</ref>
1,500 schools were damaged and destroyed during Yemeni Civil War.<ref name="urlHuge spike in Yemen violence as civilian deaths rise by 164% in four months | Global development | The Guardian">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/sep/26/huge-spike-in-yemen-violence-as-civilian-deaths-rise-by-164-in-four-months-hodeidah |title=Huge spike in Yemen violence as civilian deaths rise by 164% in four months | Global development | The Guardian |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
The UN accused the Saudi-led coalition of "complete disregard for human life".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/yemen-civil-war-saudi-arabia-air-strikes-civilian-deaths-one-day-killed-un-united-nations-a8131841.html|title=Saudi-led air strikes in Yemen killed 68 civilians in one day, UN says|publisher=}}</ref>
== Timeline ==
===October 2015 - Saada airstrike=== Doctors Without Borders reported that a Saudi Arabian-led [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|coalition]] airstrike on 26 October 2015<ref name="urlExposed: British-made bombs used on civilian targets in Yemen | Amnesty International UK">{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org.uk/exposed-british-made-bombs-used-civilian-targets-yemen |title=Exposed: British-made bombs used on civilian targets in Yemen | Amnesty International UK |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref> had completely destroyed the [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] hospital in [[Saada]], in northwestern [[Yemen]], including the operating room. The first strike hit an unused part of the hospital, so the facility was completely evacuated at once. There were no direct casualties. The spokesman for the [[coalition forces]], Brig-Gen [[Ahmad Asiri (general)|Ahmed al-Asiri]], disclaimed responsibility for the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-34645469|title=Yemen conflict: MSF hospital destroyed by air strikes|date=27 October 2015|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref>
"With the hospital destroyed, at least 200,000 people now have no access to lifesaving medical care", MSF said. "This attack is another illustration of a complete disregard for civilians in Yemen, where bombings have become a daily routine," said Hassan Boucenine, MSF head of mission in Yemen. The GPS coordinates of the only hospital in the Haydan district were regularly shared with the Saudi-led coalition, and the roof of the facility was clearly identified with the MSF logo, he said.<ref>[http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-10/28/c_134756413.htm "MSF hospital in Yemen bombed by airstrike", ''Xinhua'' (2015-10-28)]</ref> Abdallah al-Mouallimi, the Saudi ambassador to the United Nations, said the coordinates were inaccurate, although he admitted that the airstrike was "a mistake".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/exclusive-saudi-arabia-admits-bombing-msf-hospital-in-yemen-but-faults-msf|title=Exclusive: Saudi Arabia Admits Bombing MSF Hospital in Yemen — But Faults MSF - VICE News|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref>
The UNICEF said the hospital in Saada was the 39th health center hit in Yemen since March, when the violence escalated. MSF reports that the Saudi-led coalition, supported by the British military, has been bombing hospitals across Yemen for the past 10 months. As many as 130 health facilities have been hit. "More children in Yemen may well die from a lack of medicines and healthcare than from bullets and bombs," its executive director Anthony Lake said in a statement. He added that critical shortages of fuel, medication, electricity and water could mean many more will close. [[Amnesty International]] said the strike may amount to a war crime and called for an independent investigation.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/10/27/us-yemen-security-idUSKCN0SL0VK20151027 Noah Browning, "Yemeni MSF hospital bombed, Saudi-led coalition denies responsibility", ''Reuters'' (October 27 2015)]</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/10/28/doctors-without-borders-says-saudi-led-airstrikes-bomb-yemen-hospital/ "Doctors Without Borders says Saudi-led airstrikes bomb Yemen hospital", ''Associated Press'' (October 28, 2015)]</ref>
===December 2015 - Taiz airstrike=== On December 3, 2015 an airstrike by the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]] hit a health center in [[Taiz]], wounding nine people. Two hospital staff were among the wounded. "The bombing of civilians and hospitals is a violation of international humanitarian law," said Jerome Alin, head of MSF head of mission in Yemen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-nine-wounded-saudi-led-coalition-airstrike-msf-clinic-taiz|title=Yemen: Nine Wounded in Saudi-Led Coalition Airstrike on MSF Clinic in Taiz|date=3 December 2015|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130124244/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-nine-wounded-saudi-led-coalition-airstrike-msf-clinic-taiz|archive-date=30 January 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>[http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-supported-hospital-bombed-northern-yemen "MSF-Supported Hospital Bombed in Northern Yemen", MSF (Update January 11 2016)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201064940/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-supported-hospital-bombed-northern-yemen |date=2016-02-01 }}.</ref>
===January 2016 - Razeh district airstrike=== On January 10, 2016, Shiara Hospital, supported by MSF in Razeh district, [[Saada Governorate]], Northern Yemen, was hit by a projectile and shrapnel from the Saudi-led coalition. Six people died and another 7 were injured, including three MSF staff, two of them in critical condition. Several buildings at the medical facility collapsed after the attack,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/11/world/middleeast/hospital-aided-by-doctors-without-borders-is-bombed-in-yemen.html|title=Hospital Aided by Doctors Without Borders Is Bombed in Yemen|date=11 January 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref><ref>Mark Tran, "Four patients among dead after explosion at hospital in Yemen", The Guardian (January 10, 2016).</ref><ref>Adam Withnall, "Attacks on hospitals mean people in Yemen are now too scared to go for treatment, MSF says", The Independent (January 19, 2016).</ref> although the critical areas of the hospital were not destroyed. The rocket hit a corridor leading from the main gate to the hospital buildings, with a metal fence alongside. The wounded were hit by shrapnel from the missile, and also by shards of metal from the fence. The injuries were brutal. Vickie Hawkins, Executive Director of MSF-UK, said, "... there is a risk that "errors" in war situations will become normalised—just as "collateral damage" has been normalised in people's minds since the first Gulf War. This would provide the perfect alibi for armies to shrug off accusations of war crimes and crimes against humanity. It perpetuates impunity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-even-war-hospitals-should-be-places-refuge-and-healing|title=Yemen: Even in War, Hospitals Should Be "Places of Refuge And Healing"|date=19 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130124235/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-even-war-hospitals-should-be-places-refuge-and-healing|archive-date=30 January 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref>
In a separate attack by the Saudi-led coalition, an airstrike was reported to have hit a center for the blind in the capital Sana'a, resulting in multiple injuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2016/01/05/saudi-coalition-just-bombed-a-center-for-the-blind-in-yemen/|title=Saudi Coalition Just Bombed a Center for the Blind in Yemen|last=Devereaux|first=Ryan|date=2016-01-05|website=The Intercept|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-39651265|title=Saudi blacklist call over Yemen attacks|date=2017-04-20|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-11-16}}</ref>
===August 2016 - Abs district hospital airstrike=== On August 15, 2016, after the collapse of a UN-sponsored cease-fire, an airstrike by the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]] destroyed a hospital operated by Yemen's Ministry of Health and supported by MSF and UNICEF in [[Abs District]], [[Hajjah Governorate]] in northwestern Yemen. The bombardment struck the hospital's triage area near the emergency room and killed at least 19 and wounded 24 people.<ref>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/airstrike-hits-doctors-without-borders-hospital-in-yemen/ Noah Browning and Tom Brown, "Airstrike Hits Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Yemen", '''Scientific American'''. On line, n.d.]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-death-toll-rises-19-airstrike-msf-supported-hospital?source=ADD1600U0V46|title=Yemen: Death Toll Rises to 19 in Airstrike on MSF-Supported Hospital|date=16 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017}}{{Dead link|date=September 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> At the time of the attack, there were 23 patients in the surgery ward, 25 in the maternity ward, 13 newborns and 12 patients in the pediatric ward, MSF said. The hospital had a 14-bed emergency room, a maternity unit and a surgical unit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/15/middleeast/yemen-hospital-strike/index.html|title=Airstrike hits Yemen hospital, aid group says|author1=Gul Tuysuz |author2=Steve Visser|publisher=CNN|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref> Hospital staff were among the dead and wounded. “There were no armed people there,” a witness said. The hospital was reportedly treating child victims of another airstrike on a school in the town of Haydan, in neighboring Saada province, in which 10 children died and another 30 were wounded, all between the ages of 8 and 15 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-yemen-hospital-airstrike-20160815-snap-story.html|title=At least 11 dead as airstrike hits Doctors Without Borders hospital in northern Yemen|first=Nabih|last=Bulos|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/aug/15/saudi-led-air-strike-yemen-hospital-kills-at-least-seven|title=At least 11 dead after Saudi-led coalition bombs Yemen hospital|first=Saeed Kamali|last=Dehghan|date=15 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017|via=The Guardian}}</ref> MSF has now withdrawn its staff members from Haydan, Razeh, Al Gamouri and Yasnim hospitals in Saada governorate and Abs and Al Gamouri hospitals in Hajjah governorate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-evacuates-staff-six-hospitals-northern-yemen|title=MSF Evacuates Staff from Six Hospitals in Northern Yemen|date=18 August 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211015017/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-evacuates-staff-six-hospitals-northern-yemen|archive-date=11 February 2017|url-status=dead}}</ref> [[Ban Ki-moon]], the United Nations secretary general, condemned the attack in a statement, emphasizing that antagonists in the Yemen conflict had damaged or destroyed more than 70 health facilities since the hostilities began 17 months ago.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/16/world/middleeast/yemen-doctors-without-borders-hospital-bombing.html|title=Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Yemen Kills at Least 15|date=16 August 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref>
===June 2018 - Airstrike on cholera treatment center in Abs=== Doctors Without Borders reported that a Saudi Arabian [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|coalition]] airstrike struck a new [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] cholera treatment center in [[Abs (Yemen)|Abs]], in northwestern [[Yemen]]. Doctors Without Borders reported that they had provided [[GPS]] coordinates to The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia on twelve separate occasions, and had received nine written responses confirming receipt of those coordinates <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/news-stories/story/yemen-airstrike-hits-msf-cholera-treatment-center-abs|title=Yemen: Airstrike hits cholera treatment center in Abs|date=12 June 2018|publisher=|accessdate=27 June 2018}}</ref>
===2 August 2018 - Hudaydah hospital airstrike===
On 2 August 2018, airstrikes on hospital, [[harbor]] and [[fish market]] in [[Al Hudaydah]] killed at least 55 people and wounded 124.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/08/casualties-saudi-led-coalition-air-raids-hit-yemen-hodeidah-180802163441327.html|title='It was a massacre': Dozens killed in Saudi air raids on Hodeidah|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.presstv.com/Detail/2018/08/02/570023/Yemen-Hudaydah-Hudaydah-hospital-Saudi-arabia|title=PressTV-Saudi attack on Hudaydah hospital, fishing harbor kills 55|publisher=}}</ref>
===March 26, 2019 - Saada hospital airstrike=== A [[missile]] blew up a [[gas station]] near a hospital in [[Saada Governorate]], which damaged the hospital and killed seven civilians.<ref name="urlHospital hit in air strike as Yemenis mark four years of war">{{cite web |url=https://www.france24.com/en/20190327-hospital-hit-air-strike-yemen-houthi-rally-4-years-war |title=Hospital hit in air strike as Yemenis mark four years of war |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
===7 April 2019 airstrike=== Air raids by a Saudi-UAE-led coalition killed at least 11 civilians, including school children and left more than 39 people wounded in Sanaa, according to an [[Al Jazeera]] report. Also The [[Associated Press]] said 13 were killed, including 7 children, and more than 100 were wounded. [[Daily Mail]] reported a total of 54 wounded and 11 children killed in Sanaa. Youssef al-Hadrii, a spokesman for the Houthi-controlled health ministry, said most of the children killed in the bombing of houses and a school since the war beginning. There was no comment from the coalition.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saudi-led air raids 'kill at least 11 civilians' in Yemen's Sanaa |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/04/saudi-led-air-raids-kill-11-civilians-yemen-sanaa-190407201257046.html |accessdate=8 April 2019 |agency=Aljazeera |publisher=aljazeera.com |date=7 April 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Explosion in Yemen Warehouse Kills at Least 13, Including 7 Children |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/07/world/middleeast/yemen-explosion-warehouse.html |accessdate=8 April 2019 |agency=Nytimes |publisher=nytimes.com |date=7 April 2019}}</ref>
===6 November 2019 attack=== According to aid group and Yemeni officials, 8 people including 3 civilians were killed by a Houthi drone and missile strike attack in Mocha that targeted a refugee camp and a hospital ran by Doctors without Borders, causing the hospital to shut down.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/yemeni-officials-rebels-attack-government-forces-8-killed/2019/11/06/5d83df7a-00ce-11ea-8341-cc3dce52e7de_story.html%3foutputType=amp|title=Yemeni officials: Rebels missile, drone attack kills 8|author=The Washington Post|date=6 November 2019}}</ref>
